Award.AwardTitle: International Collaboration in Chemistry: Molecules at Nanostructured Surfaces for Solar Cell Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is made by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry program of the Chemistry Division within the International Collaboration in Chemistry between US investigators and their counterparts in Spain and is co-funded by the Office of International Science and Engineering. The recipient is Professor Franz Himpsel of the University of Wisconsin-Madison.

This project aims at systematically improving the efficiency of low-cost, dye-sensitized solar cells using a feedback loop between the synthesis of tailored molecules (dyes, donors, acceptors), the spectroscopy of their energy levels, and the theoretical explanation of the spectra, which will be used to identify new molecular structures to be synthesized. Organic molecules excel not only by their low cost, but they also are extremely versatile and allow a wide variety of chemical modifications. The feedback loop has five stages: 1) obtain a library of energy levels in molecules relevant to solar cells, 2) perform excited state calculations and analyze the spectroscopic data from NEXAFS and photoemission, 3) synthesize tailored molecules, based on trends observed experimentally under (1), the theoretical predictions from (2), and the capabilities of synthetic chemistry, 4) explore changes of the electronic structure near nano-structured electrodes, and 5) explore changes of the molecular electronic structure at metallic contacts.

A key challenge to photovoltaic power generation is reducing cost. The current dye-sensitized solar cell design is dominated by expensive Ru-based dyes and has reached a plateau in efficiency. The broad systematic investigation of organic dyes in this project is timely, enabling a full feedback cycle (synthesis, analysis, prediction) to optimize molecules and substrates for solar cells. The project is collaborative between Spain and US chemists, including an exchange of researchers, and postdoctoral and graduate student internships in the partner international institution. Researchers in this project are actively engaged in outreach activities leveraged with several institutional programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The energy problem is one of the biggest challenges to our society today. Solar energy is arguably the cleanest and most elegant way to tap into new energy resources. There is more than enough solar power available: an area of 100x100 square kilometers would be sufficient to satisfy all the electricity needs of the US. The total roof area in the US is larger than that. And solar cells convert solar energy directly to electricity, which is convertible into all other types of energy without loss of efficiency.

    This project takes a fresh look at how solar cells are designed. Rather than incrementally improving an existing design (such as silicon solar cells), the idea is to find the best sequence of energy levels for obtaining high efficiency and then searching for the right materials that exhibit such energy levels. Instead of a single semiconductor, one can actually use three different materials, one optimized for absorbing light, a second for extracting the electrons, and a third to fill the holes that the electrons left behind. This is shown on the primary image. In optimizing the energy levels, there are challenging trade-offs to be made. Minimizing the drop between the energy levels for in- and out-going electrons gives the highest voltage but reduces the current. Maximizing it gives the optimum current at reduced voltage.

    Specifically, we have measured the energy level structure of a variety of metal-organic dye molecules using soft X-rays from synchrotron radiation. As shown on one of the images, this technique allows us to zero in on the energy levels associated with different atoms in a molecule. This allows us to know exactly where inside a molecule or a semiconductor we need to make modifications for best performance. The results from this year were disseminated in six publications and several invited talks at conferences. Overall, we have published 11 papers in widely-accessible journals, with more to be submitted. 

    With the data on energy levels in hand we ask our collaborating theorists to explain the results in detail and to suggest the most promising modifications. These blueprints then go to synthetic chemists in the collaboration, who tell us whether or not such material can actually be made. Then the ball comes back to the X-ray spectroscopists in the collaboration, to check whether the energy levels are where we expect them.

    In the future, we would like to insert an additional link into this loop, where the performance of new materials is tested in prototype solar cells. This requires an array of fabrication techniques combined with new expertise that will require an expansion of the current collaboration.
